title: Jude Chapter 1 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Jude chapter 1 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Jude Chapter 1 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Jude Chapter 1.

questions.question: Who is the author of the letter in Jude 1:1?
questions.correctAnswer: Jude
questions.explanation: Jude identifies himself as the author in Jude 1:1.

questions.question: According to Jude 1:3, what should believers earnestly contend for?
questions.correctAnswer: The faith
questions.explanation: Jude urges believers to earnestly contend for the faith once delivered to the saints in Jude 1:3.

questions.question: In Jude 1:4, what do the ungodly men turn the grace of God into?
questions.correctAnswer: Lasciviousness
questions.explanation: Verse 4 states that ungodly men turn the grace of God into lasciviousness.

questions.question: What does Jude 1:6 say about angels who kept not their first estate?
options: They are reserved in everlasting chains under darkness
questions.correctAnswer: They are reserved in everlasting chains under darkness
questions.explanation: Jude 1:6 explains that such angels are reserved in everlasting chains under darkness for judgment.

questions.question: According to Jude 1:7, which cities are set forth as an example of suffering eternal fire?
questions.correctAnswer: Sodom and Gomorrha
questions.explanation: Verse 7 mentions Sodom and Gomorrha and the cities around them as examples of eternal fire.

questions.question: In Jude 1:9, who contended with the devil over the body of Moses?
questions.correctAnswer: Michael the archangel
questions.explanation: Michael the archangel disputed with the devil about Moses' body as stated in Jude 1:9.

questions.question: Which three examples of ungodly behavior are given in Jude 1:16?
options: Murmurers, complainers, walking after their own lusts
questions.correctAnswer: Murmurers, complainers, walking after their own lusts
questions.explanation: Verse 16 describes them as murmurers, complainers, and walking after their own lusts.

questions.question: What should believers do according to Jude 1:20?
options: Build up themselves on their most holy faith, praying in the Holy Ghost
questions.correctAnswer: Build up themselves on their most holy faith, praying in the Holy Ghost
questions.explanation: Jude 1:20 instructs believers to build themselves up on their holy faith and pray in the Holy Ghost.

questions.question: Who prophesied about the coming of the Lord with ten thousands of his saints, as mentioned in Jude 1:14?
questions.correctAnswer: Enoch
questions.explanation: Verse 14 states that Enoch, seventh from Adam, prophesied this event.

questions.question: According to Jude 1:18, what did the apostles say would come in the last time?
options: Mockers who walk after their own ungodly lusts
questions.correctAnswer: Mockers who walk after their own ungodly lusts
questions.explanation: Verse 18 says apostles warned about mockers in the last time following ungodly lusts.

questions.question: True or False: Jude 1:11 compares the ungodly men to the way of Cain, the error of Balaam, and the gainsaying of Core.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jude 1:11 specifically references these three examples of ungodly behavior.

questions.question: True or False: According to Jude 1:24, God is able to keep believers from falling and present them faultless with joy.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 24 affirms God's power to keep believers from falling and present them faultless.

questions.question: True or False: Jude 1:10 says that these ungodly men speak evil of what they know naturally, like brute beasts.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 10 describes how they speak evil of things they do not understand, corrupting themselves like brute beasts.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Jude 1:21: 'Keep yourselves in the love of God, looking for the mercy of our Lord Jesus Christ unto ________.'
questions.correctAnswer: eternal life
questions.explanation: Verse 21 instructs believers to look for mercy unto eternal life.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Jude 1:25: 'To the only wise God our Saviour, be glory and majesty, dominion and power, both now and ________.'
questions.correctAnswer: ever
questions.explanation: Verse 25 ends with 'both now and ever.'

medium.title: Jude Chapter 1 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Jude Chapter 1 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with doubts about the faith. Based on Jude 1, what biblical truth would you share about defending the faith?
options: Earnestly contend for the faith once delivered to the saints
Ignore doubts as they will pass on their own
Focus only on personal spiritual growth without addressing faith
Avoid discussions about faith to prevent conflict
questions.correctAnswer: Earnestly contend for the faith once delivered to the saints
questions.explanation: Jude 1:3 exhorts believers to earnestly contend for the faith once delivered to the saints, emphasizing proactive defense and commitment. This is supported by warnings against ungodly influences (Jude 1:4) and remembering the apostles' words about mockers (Jude 1:17-18).

questions.question: How does Jude 1 teach us about God's protection in times of spiritual struggle?
options: God preserves believers in Jesus Christ
Protection comes only through human wisdom
There is no protection in spiritual struggles
questions.correctAnswer: God preserves believers in Jesus Christ
questions.explanation: Jude 1:1 states that believers are preserved in Jesus Christ, assuring God's sustaining power through trials. This is affirmed by God’s ability to keep believers from falling and present them faultless (Jude 1:24), encouraging trust and perseverance.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to compromise Christian values for personal gain. What warning from Jude 1 would you share?
options: Woe unto them who run after error for reward
Gain is more important than spiritual integrity
Ignoring temptation is the best defense
questions.correctAnswer: Woe unto them who run after error for reward
questions.explanation: Jude 1:11 warns against greedily running after the error of Balaam for reward, highlighting the danger of compromising for gain. This is linked to the condemnation of ungodly men (Jude 1:4) and consequences of rebellion (Jude 1:5).

questions.question: How does Jude 1 encourage believers to maintain their spiritual vitality?
options: Building up yourselves on your most holy faith, praying in the Holy Ghost
Focusing only on good works without faith
Relying solely on church leaders for spiritual growth
questions.correctAnswer: Building up yourselves on your most holy faith, praying in the Holy Ghost
questions.explanation: Jude 1:20 emphasizes personal spiritual discipline through building faith and prayer in the Holy Spirit. This active devotion is essential for perseverance and spiritual strength, complementing the call to keep in God’s love (Jude 1:21).

questions.question: What counsel does Jude 1 give about dealing with divisive or ungodly people in the church?
options: Have compassion on some, save others with fear, and hate even the garment spotted by the flesh
Ignore them completely and avoid fellowship
questions.correctAnswer: Have compassion on some, save others with fear, and hate even the garment spotted by the flesh
questions.explanation: Jude 1:22-23 advises believers to show discernment: compassion for some, cautious saving for others, while abhorring sin itself. This balance reflects love and holiness, promoting church unity and purity.

questions.question: According to Jude 1, what is the ultimate destiny of ungodly sinners who reject God’s ways?
questions.correctAnswer: Blackness of darkness reserved forever
questions.explanation: Jude 1:13 describes wandering stars reserved for the blackness of darkness forever, symbolizing eternal judgment for ungodly sinners, consistent with the theme of eternal fire for Sodom and Gomorrah (Jude 1:7) and judgment described by Enoch (Jude 1:14-15).

questions.question: True or False: Jude 1 teaches that believers should look forward to the mercy of Jesus Christ unto eternal life.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jude 1:21 instructs believers to keep themselves in the love of God and look for the mercy of our Lord Jesus Christ unto eternal life, encouraging hope and endurance in the Christian walk.

questions.question: True or False: Jude 1 says that Michael the archangel accused the devil harshly during their dispute about Moses' body.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jude 1:9 states that Michael did not bring a railing accusation against the devil but said, 'The Lord rebuke thee,' showing humility and reliance on God's authority rather than personal confrontation.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Jude 1:24, God is able to keep you from _____ and present you faultless before His presence with exceeding joy.
questions.correctAnswer: falling
questions.explanation: Jude 1:24 assures believers that God is able to keep them from falling and present them faultless before His glorious presence, emphasizing divine preservation and joy in salvation.

questions.question: How does Jude 1 describe those who cause division in the church and follow their own ungodly lusts?
options: They are sensual, having not the Spirit, and separate themselves
They are humble and teach others gently
They build up the body of Christ with love
questions.correctAnswer: They are sensual, having not the Spirit, and separate themselves
questions.explanation: Jude 1:19 describes such people as sensual, lacking the Spirit, and separating themselves, highlighting their disruptive and ungodly nature.

questions.question: What example from the Old Testament does Jude 1 use to warn against disbelief and disobedience?
options: The people saved from Egypt who afterward perished for unbelief
The building of the Tower of Babel
questions.correctAnswer: The people saved from Egypt who afterward perished for unbelief
questions.explanation: Jude 1:5 reminds believers that although the Lord saved the people out of Egypt, He destroyed those who did not believe, illustrating the consequences of unbelief and disobedience.

questions.question: Based on Jude 1, what attitude should believers have towards spiritual warnings given by the apostles?
options: Remember and heed their words about mockers and ungodly lusts
questions.correctAnswer: Remember and heed their words about mockers and ungodly lusts
questions.explanation: Jude 1:17-18 urges believers to remember the apostles' warnings about mockers in the last times who follow ungodly lusts, emphasizing the importance of vigilance and obedience to apostolic teaching.

questions.question: What does Jude 1 teach about the importance of love in the Christian life?
options: Keep yourselves in the love of God
Love is less important than knowledge
Love can be ignored for discipline
Love is only for close friends
questions.correctAnswer: Keep yourselves in the love of God
questions.explanation: Jude 1:21 advises believers to keep themselves in God's love, highlighting love as a vital, ongoing spiritual condition necessary for faithfulness and looking forward to mercy.

questions.question: How does Jude 1 describe those who turn God's grace into lasciviousness and deny Jesus Christ?
questions.correctAnswer: Ungodly men ordained to condemnation
questions.explanation: Jude 1:4 warns that certain men who turn God's grace into lasciviousness and deny Jesus Christ are ungodly and ordained to condemnation, emphasizing the seriousness of false teaching and rebellion.

questions.question: What example does Jude 1 use to illustrate divine judgment on immoral cities?
options: Sodom and Gomorrah suffering eternal fire
Jericho falling at the sound of trumpets
questions.correctAnswer: Sodom and Gomorrah suffering eternal fire
questions.explanation: Jude 1:7 cites Sodom and Gomorrah as examples of cities judged for fornication and unnatural lust, illustrating the certainty of divine judgment on sin.

hard.title: Jude Chapter 1 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Jude Chapter 1.

questions.question: What is the primary exhortation Jude gives to his readers regarding the faith?
options: To earnestly contend for the faith once delivered to the saints
To establish new doctrines for the church
To avoid all forms of religious debate
To focus solely on personal salvation
questions.correctAnswer: To earnestly contend for the faith once delivered to the saints
questions.explanation: Jude 1:3 instructs believers to earnestly contend for the faith which was once delivered unto the saints, emphasizing the preservation of apostolic teaching.

questions.question: Which Old Testament figure is mentioned in Jude 1:9 in a dispute involving the devil?
questions.correctAnswer: Moses
questions.explanation: Jude 1:9 refers specifically to Michael the archangel disputing with the devil about the body of Moses, highlighting a unique angelic confrontation.

questions.question: How does Jude describe the men who have crept in unawares?
options: Ungodly men turning the grace of God into lasciviousness
questions.correctAnswer: Ungodly men turning the grace of God into lasciviousness
questions.explanation: Jude 1:4 identifies these men as ungodly, corrupting grace into licentiousness, and denying the Lord Jesus Christ.

questions.question: What Old Testament judgment does Jude remind his readers of in verse 5?
options: The destruction of those who believed not after the Exodus from Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: The destruction of those who believed not after the Exodus from Egypt
questions.explanation: Jude 1:5 recalls how the Lord saved the people from Egypt but destroyed those who did not believe, drawing on Israel’s history as a warning.

questions.question: What is the condition of the angels mentioned in Jude 1:6?
options: They kept not their first estate and are reserved in everlasting chains under darkness
They are ministering spirits sent to serve the saints
They are praised for their obedience
They are worshipped by the early church
questions.correctAnswer: They kept not their first estate and are reserved in everlasting chains under darkness
questions.explanation: Jude 1:6 describes rebellious angels who abandoned their proper place and are held in eternal chains awaiting judgment.

questions.question: What cities are used as an example of judgment in Jude 1:7?
questions.correctAnswer: Sodom and Gomorrah
questions.explanation: Jude 1:7 cites Sodom and Gomorrah and surrounding cities as examples of those who indulged in fornication and unnatural desires, suffering eternal fire.

questions.question: Jude warns that certain individuals are like "clouds without water" and "trees without fruit". What literary device is primarily used here?
questions.correctAnswer: Metaphor
questions.explanation: In Jude 1:12, the description of these individuals as 'clouds without water' and 'trees without fruit' serves as metaphors illustrating barrenness and worthlessness.

questions.question: Who does Jude say prophesied about the Lord’s coming with ten thousands of His saints?
questions.correctAnswer: Enoch
questions.explanation: Jude 1:14 explicitly mentions Enoch, the seventh from Adam, as the prophet who foretold the Lord's coming with numerous saints.

questions.question: According to Jude 1:11, whose way do the ungodly follow, among others?
questions.correctAnswer: Cain, Balaam, and Core
questions.explanation: Jude 1:11 condemns the ungodly for following the sinful examples of Cain (murder), Balaam (greed), and Core (rebellion).

questions.question: In Jude 1:16, what characteristic is NOT attributed to these false teachers?
options: They walk after their own lusts
Their mouths speak great swelling words
questions.correctAnswer: They are humble and selfless
questions.explanation: Jude 1:16 describes these individuals as murmurers, complainers, and boastful, not humble or selfless.

questions.question: What does Jude instruct the believers to do in verse 20 to strengthen themselves?
options: Build up themselves on their most holy faith, praying in the Holy Ghost
Focus solely on the Law of Moses
Seek wealth and power in the world
questions.correctAnswer: Build up themselves on their most holy faith, praying in the Holy Ghost
questions.explanation: Jude 1:20 exhorts believers to build themselves up spiritually through faith and prayer empowered by the Holy Spirit.

questions.question: How does Jude describe those who separate themselves and lack the Spirit in verse 19?
questions.correctAnswer: Sensual
questions.explanation: Jude 1:19 characterizes those who separate from the community and lack the Spirit as 'sensual', implying they live according to fleshly desires.

questions.question: What is the ultimate hope believers are encouraged to look for according to Jude 1:21?
options: The mercy of our Lord Jesus Christ unto eternal life
questions.correctAnswer: The mercy of our Lord Jesus Christ unto eternal life
questions.explanation: Jude 1:21 encourages believers to keep themselves in God's love while looking for the mercy of Jesus that leads to eternal life.

questions.question: True or False: Jude 1:24 states that God is able to keep believers from falling and present them faultless before His glory.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jude 1:24 clearly affirms God's power to preserve believers and present them blameless with great joy before His presence.

questions.question: Which theme in Jude 1:4-7 best connects with the Old Testament concept of divine judgment?
options: Condemnation of false teachers and examples of past judgments like Sodom
Celebration of God's grace without judgment
questions.correctAnswer: Condemnation of false teachers and examples of past judgments like Sodom
questions.explanation: Jude 1:4-7 links the condemnation of false teachers to historical divine judgments such as the destruction of Sodom and the fallen angels, illustrating the theme of judgment.

theological.title: Jude Chapter 1 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Jude Chapter 1 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Jude 1:3, what is the primary exhortation Jude gives to believers?
options: To earnestly contend for the faith once delivered to the saints
questions.correctAnswer: To earnestly contend for the faith once delivered to the saints
questions.explanation: Jude 1:3 exhorts believers to 'earnestly contend for the faith which was once delivered unto the saints.' This aligns with Paul's instruction in Philippians 1:27 to stand fast in one spirit, and the call in 1 Timothy 6:12 to fight the good fight of faith. Contending for the faith guards against false teachings as warned in 2 Timothy 4:7 and Titus 1:9.

questions.question: What describes the false teachers Jude warns about in Jude 1:4?
options: Ungodly men turning the grace of God into lasciviousness and denying Jesus Christ
questions.correctAnswer: Ungodly men turning the grace of God into lasciviousness and denying Jesus Christ
questions.explanation: Jude 1:4 describes false teachers as 'ungodly men, turning the grace of our God into lasciviousness, and denying the only Lord God, and our Lord Jesus Christ.' This is consistent with warnings about false teachers in 2 Peter 2:1-3, 1 John 4:1, and Acts 20:29-30, who pervert grace and deny Christ’s lordship.

questions.question: What example from the Old Testament does Jude use in verse 5 to remind believers of God's judgment?
options: The destruction of those who did not believe after being saved from Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: The destruction of those who did not believe after being saved from Egypt
questions.explanation: Jude 1:5 references how the Lord, after saving the people from Egypt, destroyed those who did not believe. This recalls the wilderness rebellion (Numbers 14), emphasizing God’s judgment on unbelief consistent with Hebrews 3:16-19 and Psalm 95:7-11.

questions.question: According to Jude 1:6, what happened to the angels who 'kept not their first estate'?
options: They are reserved in everlasting chains under darkness unto judgment
They were sent to minister to the saints
questions.correctAnswer: They are reserved in everlasting chains under darkness unto judgment
questions.explanation: Jude 1:6 states that angels who abandoned their proper place are kept in everlasting chains for judgment. This aligns with 2 Peter 2:4 and Genesis 6:1-4, illustrating divine judgment on rebellious spiritual beings.

questions.question: What cities does Jude mention in verse 7 as examples of divine judgment for immorality?
questions.correctAnswer: Sodom and Gomorrah
questions.explanation: Jude 1:7 cites Sodom and Gomorrah as examples of cities judged for fornication and unnatural desires. This mirrors Genesis 19 and is referenced in 2 Peter 2:6 and Luke 17:29 as warnings against immorality and divine wrath.

questions.question: In Jude 1:9, who contended with the devil over the body of Moses?
questions.correctAnswer: Michael the archangel
questions.explanation: Jude 1:9 identifies Michael the archangel as disputing with the devil over Moses' body. This unique reference highlights angelic authority and restraint, consistent with Daniel 10:13 and Revelation 12:7 where Michael leads heavenly battles.

questions.question: What characterizes the false teachers according to Jude 1:10?
options: They speak evil of things they do not understand and corrupt themselves like brute beasts
They are humble and teach with love
questions.correctAnswer: They speak evil of things they do not understand and corrupt themselves like brute beasts
questions.explanation: Jude 1:10 describes false teachers as speaking evil ignorantly and corrupting themselves, similar to irrational animals. This echoes 2 Peter 2:12 and Psalm 73:22, showing the folly of ungodly speech and behavior.

questions.question: Which three Old Testament figures’ errors are referenced in Jude 1:11 as examples of ungodliness?
questions.correctAnswer: Cain, Balaam, and Core
questions.explanation: Jude 1:11 condemns those following the sinful paths of Cain (murder and envy), Balaam (greedy error), and Core (rebellion). These examples align with Genesis 4:8, Numbers 22-24, and Numbers 16, illustrating patterns of rebellion and greed.

questions.question: How does Jude describe false teachers in verse 12 using metaphors?
options: Spots in your feasts of charity, clouds without water, and trees without fruit
Bright stars, flowing rivers, and fruitful branches
Wise counselors, strong foundations, and faithful servants
Lamps of the world, salt of the earth, and pillars in the church
questions.correctAnswer: Spots in your feasts of charity, clouds without water, and trees without fruit
questions.explanation: Jude 1:12 uses metaphors showing false teachers as blemishes and unproductive elements—spots, waterless clouds, and fruitless trees—highlighting their harmful presence. This aligns with Matthew 7:15-20 and 2 Peter 2:13.

questions.question: What is the prophecy of Enoch mentioned in Jude 1:14 concerning the Lord’s coming?
options: The Lord comes with ten thousands of his saints to execute judgment
The Lord will establish an earthly kingdom
The Lord will send a new prophet
The Lord will bring peace to all nations
questions.correctAnswer: The Lord comes with ten thousands of his saints to execute judgment
questions.explanation: Jude 1:14 quotes Enoch's prophecy of the Lord coming with many saints to judge ungodly deeds. This anticipates Christ’s second coming described in Revelation 19:11-16, Daniel 7:13-14, and 2 Thessalonians 1:7-8.

questions.question: According to Jude 1:16, what motivates the false teachers’ speech and behavior?
options: Their own lusts and admiration of people for advantage
A desire to serve God humbly
questions.correctAnswer: Their own lusts and admiration of people for advantage
questions.explanation: Jude 1:16 describes false teachers as complainers whose speech is inflated and motivated by selfish desires and seeking favor for personal gain. This is consistent with 2 Timothy 3:2-5 and Philippians 2:3.

questions.question: What does Jude instruct believers to build themselves up in, according to verse 20?
options: Most holy faith, praying in the Holy Ghost
questions.correctAnswer: Most holy faith, praying in the Holy Ghost
questions.explanation: Jude 1:20 encourages believers to strengthen themselves through faith and prayer empowered by the Holy Spirit. This aligns with Ephesians 3:16-17, Romans 8:26-27, and Colossians 2:6-7.

questions.question: What is the final doxology in Jude 1:25 emphasizing about God?
options: God is only wise Saviour, deserving glory, majesty, dominion, and power forever
God is a mere moral teacher
questions.correctAnswer: God is only wise Saviour, deserving glory, majesty, dominion, and power forever
questions.explanation: Jude 1:25 glorifies God as the only wise Savior, attributing eternal glory, majesty, dominion, and power. This echoes Romans 16:27, 1 Timothy 1:17, and Revelation 4:11, affirming God's eternal sovereignty and wisdom.

questions.question: What attitude toward others does Jude advocate in verses 22-23 regarding different types of sinners?
options: Have compassion on some, save others with fear, hating even the garment spotted by the flesh
questions.correctAnswer: Have compassion on some, save others with fear, hating even the garment spotted by the flesh
questions.explanation: Jude 1:22-23 urges believers to differentiate in their response—showing compassion to some and saving others with caution, hating sin’s contamination. This reflects Jesus’ teaching in Matthew 18:15-17 and Paul’s counsel in Galatians 6:1.

questions.question: What does Jude say believers should do to 'keep yourselves in the love of God' in verse 21?
options: Look for the mercy of our Lord Jesus Christ unto eternal life
questions.correctAnswer: Look for the mercy of our Lord Jesus Christ unto eternal life
questions.explanation: Jude 1:21 instructs believers to remain in God's love by anticipating Christ’s mercy that leads to eternal life. This is consistent with 1 Corinthians 13:13, Romans 8:38-39, and Titus 3:7.
